title: 103_s1741
content: The Act titled "Government Air Travel Savings Act of 1993" mandates business accounts for federal employees' air travel. The "Government Air Travel Savings Act of 1993" requires federal agencies to establish business accounts with air carriers for official employee travel, including depositing any awards or bonuses into the employee's account. The "Government Air Travel Savings Act of 1993" mandates federal agencies to set up business accounts with air carriers for official employee travel, depositing awards or bonuses into the employee's account for travel purposes. The "Government Air Travel Savings Act of 1993" requires federal agencies to establish air travel business accounts for official employee travel. Awards or bonuses must be deposited into the employee's account for official travel purposes, excluding seating upgrades. The General Services Administration must include terms in contracts to save on travel costs. Employees must use awards and bonuses from air carriers for official business travel only. Regulations will be promulgated to enforce these provisions. Employees must use awards and bonuses from air carriers for official business travel only, excluding seating upgrades. Employees must use awards and bonuses from air carriers for official business travel only, excluding seating upgrades. SEC. 2. APPLICATION TO THE CONGRESS. The Committees on Rules and Administration of the Senate and Administration of the House must create regulations within 180 days of this Act's enactment regarding Members of Congress and employees paid by the Senate Secretary or House Clerk. These regulations require Members and officers entering into air travel contracts for official business to include terms that the air carrier must establish separate air travel. The regulations require the air carrier to establish a separate air travel business account for Members and employees for official business travel, deposit any awards or bonuses into the account, and apply them to official business travel expenses. The air carrier must establish a separate air travel business account for official business travel by Members and employees, deposit any awards or bonuses into the account, and use them for official business travel expenses. The text discusses the allocation of awards or bonuses from an air travel business account for official business travel by Members and employees of a committee or office. It also emphasizes maximizing travel cost savings by requiring contracts with air carriers. Members' offices can enter contracts with air carriers for awards and bonuses for official business travel. Members and employees must travel with these carriers and participate in their programs, using awards and bonuses for official business travel only. Seating upgrades are not allowed. Members and employees must establish separate air travel business accounts for official business travel. Awards and bonuses from these accounts can only be used for official business travel, not for seating upgrades. Members of Congress and officers should include cost-saving terms in contracts with air carriers.
